name: Chinese History: Dynasties to the People's Republic

chapters.name: Imperial Foundations: The Qin and Han Dynasties
topics: How did the Qin Dynasty (221-206 BCE) — lasting only 15 years — permanently shape China by unifying the writing system, standardizing weights and measures, building the first Great Wall sections, and establishing the template for centralized imperial rule?

Why did the Han Dynasty (206 BCE-220 CE) endure for over 400 years, and how did its civil service examination system, Confucian state ideology, and Silk Road trade create the cultural framework that defines Chinese identity today?

What was the significance of the Mandate of Heaven doctrine in Chinese politics — how did it simultaneously legitimize ruling dynasties and justify their overthrow when they lost heaven's favor through corruption or incompetence?
How did the Han Dynasty's population of 60 million — comparable to the Roman Empire — sustain itself through advanced agriculture, iron technology, and a state monopoly on salt and iron?
What caused the collapse of the Han Dynasty in 220 CE, and how did the subsequent Three Kingdoms period (220-280 CE) become the most romanticized era in Chinese literature and culture?

Why do Chinese people still call themselves 'Han people' (Han ren) and Chinese characters 'Han characters' (Han zi) — what does this persistence reveal about the dynasty's foundational role in Chinese civilization?

chapters.name: The Tang and Song: China's Golden Ages
topics: How did the Tang Dynasty (618-907 CE) create what many historians consider the most cosmopolitan civilization in the world — with Chang'an (population one million) hosting merchants, monks, and diplomats from Persia, India, Japan, and the Byzantine Empire?

What technological innovations did Song Dynasty China (960-1279) achieve — movable type printing, gunpowder weapons, magnetic compass navigation, paper money — and why did these inventions transform the world only after they reached Europe centuries later?
How did the imperial examination system evolve from the Han through the Tang and Song into the most sophisticated meritocratic civil service in the pre-modern world — and what were its blind spots?

Why did foot-binding begin during the Song Dynasty, and how did this practice — which crippled an estimated 2 billion women over a thousand years — become both a symbol of female subjugation and a marker of social status?

What was the Song Dynasty's 'economic revolution' — with urbanization rates exceeding 20%, iron production rivaling 18th-century Britain, and a merchant class that challenged Confucian social hierarchies?

How did the Mongol conquest of the Song Dynasty (completed 1279) end China's most innovative era, and why did the subsequent Yuan Dynasty under Kublai Khan produce both cultural fusion and Chinese resentment of foreign rule?

chapters.name: The Ming Dynasty: Exploration, Isolation, and the Great Wall
topics: How did the Ming Dynasty (1368-1644) — founded by a peasant rebel who expelled the Mongols — restore Chinese rule and create the iconic Great Wall, Forbidden City, and porcelain trade that define China in the Western imagination?

What were the voyages of Zheng He (1405-1433) — seven expeditions with fleets of up to 300 ships and 27,000 men reaching Africa — and why did China abruptly abandon maritime exploration, one of history's most consequential decisions?

How did the Ming 'sea ban' policy (haijin) of the 1430s — prohibiting private maritime trade and dismantling the treasure fleet — represent a deliberate turn inward that ceded the world's oceans to European powers?
What was the role of the eunuchs in Ming court politics — how did castrated palace servants accumulate enough power to control emperors, command armies, and run intelligence networks?
How did the arrival of Portuguese traders at Macau (1557) and Jesuit missionaries like Matteo Ricci (1583) begin China's encounter with European science, religion, and commercial ambitions?
Why did the Ming Dynasty collapse in 1644 — what combination of fiscal crisis, famine, peasant rebellion (Li Zicheng), and Manchu invasion destroyed a dynasty that had lasted 276 years?

chapters.name: The Qing Dynasty: The Last Empire
topics: How did the Manchus — a non-Chinese ethnic minority from Manchuria — conquer China and establish the Qing Dynasty (1644-1912), and what strategies of cultural accommodation and military force allowed them to rule for 268 years?

What was the 'High Qing' under the Kangxi (r. 1661-1722), Yongzheng (r. 1722-1735), and Qianlong (r. 1735-1796) emperors — a period when China's population doubled to 300 million, territory expanded to include Tibet and Xinjiang, and the economy produced an estimated one-third of global GDP?

How did the Qing's 'queue order' — forcing all Chinese men to shave their foreheads and wear the Manchu braid on pain of death — become both a symbol of conquest and, paradoxically, a symbol of Chinese identity that revolutionaries later cut off?
What was the Canton System (1757-1842), which restricted all European trade to a single port and a handful of licensed merchants, and why did this system's rigidity ultimately provoke the Opium Wars?

How did the Qing Dynasty's demographic explosion — from 150 million in 1700 to 430 million by 1850 — strain resources, fuel land hunger, and create the conditions for the massive rebellions that nearly destroyed the empire?

Why do Chinese historians view the Qing's final century (1840-1912) as the 'Century of Humiliation' — a period of unequal treaties, foreign concessions, and national degradation that still shapes Chinese foreign policy?

chapters.name: The Opium Wars and the Century of Humiliation
topics: How did Britain's addiction to Chinese tea — consuming 30 million pounds annually by 1830 — create a trade imbalance that the British East India Company 'solved' by smuggling Indian opium into China?

What happened when Commissioner Lin Zexu destroyed 1,400 tons of British opium in Canton in 1839, and why did Britain respond with a war (1839-1842) that forced China to cede Hong Kong and open five treaty ports?

How did the Treaty of Nanking (1842) and subsequent 'unequal treaties' strip China of tariff autonomy, grant foreigners extraterritorial legal immunity, and establish the foreign concessions that turned Shanghai into a semi-colonial city?

What was the Second Opium War (1856-1860), and how did the Anglo-French destruction and looting of the Summer Palace (Yuanmingyuan) — one of the world's architectural wonders — become a symbol of Western barbarism in Chinese memory?

How did the Taiping Rebellion (1850-1864) — led by Hong Xiuquan, who claimed to be Jesus Christ's younger brother — kill an estimated 20-30 million people, making it the deadliest civil war in human history?

Why did the 'Self-Strengthening Movement' (1861-1895) — China's attempt to adopt Western military technology while preserving Confucian values — fail to prevent further defeats, including the humiliating loss to Japan in 1895?

chapters.name: Revolution: From the Boxer Uprising to the Republic
topics: What was the Boxer Rebellion of 1899-1901 — when a martial arts movement besieged foreign legations in Beijing — and how did the eight-nation military intervention and punitive indemnity of 450 million taels of silver further humiliate the Qing?

How did Sun Yat-sen's 'Three Principles of the People' (nationalism, democracy, livelihood) provide the ideological framework for the Xinhai Revolution of 1911 that ended 2,000 years of imperial rule?

Why did the Republic of China (established 1912) immediately descend into chaos — with Yuan Shikai's attempted restoration of monarchy, the warlord era, and competing governments in Beijing and Guangzhou?

What was the May Fourth Movement of 1919, how did Chinese outrage over the Versailles Treaty's transfer of German concessions in Shandong to Japan — rather than returning them to China — radicalize an entire generation?

How did the Chinese Communist Party, founded in 1921 by 13 delegates including Mao Zedong, grow from a tiny Marxist study group into a mass movement — and what role did Soviet advisors play in its early development?

What was the Shanghai Massacre of April 12, 1927, when Chiang Kai-shek's Nationalists killed thousands of Communists and unionists in a single day — beginning a civil war that would last (with interruptions) until 1949?

chapters.name: War, Civil War, and Communist Victory
topics: How did the Long March (1934-1935) — a 6,000-mile retreat that reduced the Communist army from 86,000 to 8,000 survivors — paradoxically strengthen the CCP by forging a hardened leadership under Mao Zedong?

What was the Second Sino-Japanese War (1937-1945), and how did Japan's brutal occupation — including the Nanjing Massacre, Unit 731's biological experiments, and the 'Three Alls' policy (kill all, burn all, loot all) — kill an estimated 15-20 million Chinese?

How did the Chinese Civil War resume after Japan's defeat, and why did Chiang Kai-shek's Nationalists — despite superior numbers, American support, and control of China's cities — lose to Mao's Communists by October 1949?
What mistakes did Chiang Kai-shek make — hyperinflation, corruption, alienation of the peasantry, military overextension — that turned a winning position in 1946 into complete defeat by 1949?

How did Mao Zedong proclaim the People's Republic of China on October 1, 1949, declaring 'the Chinese people have stood up' — and what did this statement mean in the context of the Century of Humiliation?

What happened to the 2 million Nationalists who fled to Taiwan with Chiang Kai-shek, and how did this retreat create the Taiwan Strait crisis that remains one of the world's most dangerous flashpoints?

chapters.name: Mao's China: Revolution, Famine, and Cultural Revolution
topics: How did the Chinese Communist Party's land reform campaign (1949-1953) redistribute land from landlords to peasants while executing an estimated 1-2 million 'class enemies' in public struggle sessions?

What was the Great Leap Forward (1958-1962), how did Mao's attempt to industrialize China overnight through backyard steel furnaces and agricultural collectivization cause the deadliest famine in human history — an estimated 30-45 million dead?

Why did the Great Leap Forward's death toll remain hidden for decades — with local officials reporting false harvest numbers to avoid punishment while millions starved — and what does this reveal about the pathologies of authoritarian systems?

What was the Cultural Revolution (1966-1976), how did Mao unleash millions of Red Guards to attack 'bourgeois' culture, destroy temples and artifacts, humiliate intellectuals, and purge rivals — and why did Chinese society tear itself apart?
How many people died during the Cultural Revolution — with estimates ranging from 500,000 to 2 million — and why has the Chinese government never conducted a full accounting?
What was the Sino-Soviet split, and how did ideological rivalry between Mao and Khrushchev transform the communist world from a unified bloc into competing factions that nearly went to war in 1969?

chapters.name: Deng Xiaoping and the Economic Miracle
topics: How did Deng Xiaoping — purged twice during the Cultural Revolution — emerge after Mao's death (1976) to launch economic reforms that would lift 800 million people out of poverty over the next four decades?
What was 'socialism with Chinese characteristics,' and how did Deng's Special Economic Zones (starting with Shenzhen in 1980) create capitalist enclaves within a nominally communist system?

What happened at Tiananmen Square on June 4, 1989, when the People's Liberation Army killed an estimated hundreds to thousands of pro-democracy protesters — and how has China erased this event from domestic memory?

How did China's GDP grow from $150 billion in 1978 to over $18 trillion by 2023 — the fastest sustained economic expansion in human history — and what combination of state planning, market forces, and global trade made it possible?

What was the social cost of China's economic miracle — the 300 million rural migrants living as second-class citizens in cities, the environmental devastation, the suppression of labor rights and political freedom?
How did Deng's formula of 'economic reform without political reform' create a system that delivered prosperity while maintaining one-party rule — and can this formula survive indefinitely?

chapters.name: Xi Jinping and China's Global Ambitions
topics: How did Xi Jinping consolidate power after 2012 — abolishing presidential term limits, purging rivals through anti-corruption campaigns, and establishing a personality cult — reversing the collective leadership model that had governed China since Mao's death?

What is the Belt and Road Initiative, and how does China's infrastructure investment across 140+ countries represent both a development program and a bid for global influence that challenges American hegemony?

How did China's repression of the Uyghur population in Xinjiang — with an estimated 1 million people held in 're-education camps' — demonstrate the CCP's willingness to use mass detention against ethnic minorities?

What is the significance of China's crackdown on Hong Kong's autonomy (2019-2020), including the National Security Law that effectively ended the 'one country, two systems' arrangement promised until 2047?
How has China's military modernization — including the world's largest navy by ship count, hypersonic missiles, and space capabilities — transformed the strategic balance in the Indo-Pacific?

Why does Taiwan remain the most dangerous flashpoint in global geopolitics, and how does the island's semiconductor dominance (producing 90% of the world's advanced chips) make its fate a matter of global economic survival?
